chapters.title: Why This Book
chapters.subtitle: When Code Is No Longer the Bottleneck
chapters.excerpt: I am writing this book because I believe we have reached the end of a long chapter in the history of software development — and the beginning of another for which we do not yet have a playbook.

chapters.title: The Two Engineering Organizations Most of Us Actually Work In
chapters.subtitle: Traditional vs Agile Organizations
chapters.excerpt: Most engineering organizations fall into two categories: traditional engineering orgs, and reasonably mature (but imperfect) agile organizations. Understanding where we are is crucial before we can evolve.
chapters.section: Part 1 — Where We Are (Reality, Not Ideals)

chapters.title: Why These Models Worked for a Long Time
chapters.subtitle: Understanding the Historical Context
chapters.excerpt: The way most engineering organizations work today is not accidental. It is the result of years—sometimes decades—of practical learning under very real constraints. And for a long time, these models didn't just exist. They worked.
chapters.section: Part 1 — Where We Are (Reality, Not Ideals)

chapters.title: The Invisible Cost of Modern Engineering
chapters.subtitle: Why Everything Feels So Slow
chapters.excerpt: By most visible measures, modern engineering organizations look busy. Jira boards are full, sprints are packed, standups happen every day. People are working hard. And yet, almost everywhere, the same sentence keeps coming up: 'Why does everything still feel so slow?'
chapters.section: Part 1 — Where We Are (Reality, Not Ideals)

chapters.title: When Writing Code Stops Being the Center of Gravity
chapters.subtitle: The Personal Journey of Discovery
chapters.excerpt: For some time, I had been exploring business ideas as part of my entrepreneurial journey. I kept returning to one question: Where can technology create real impact in an industry that still runs mostly manually? That question led me to textiles. And to a realization that changed everything.
chapters.section: Part 2 — What Actually Changed (Not the Hype)

chapters.title: How AI Quietly Breaks Existing Assumptions
chapters.subtitle: The Structural Implications
chapters.excerpt: The shift we explored in the previous chapter is not just personal. It is structural. If writing code is no longer the bottleneck, then the entire engineering organization — as we designed it over the past 20 years — rests on an assumption that may no longer hold.
chapters.section: Part 2 — What Actually Changed (Not the Hype)

chapters.title: Why Old SDLC Thinking Starts Lying to You
chapters.subtitle: When Processes Become Misleading
chapters.excerpt: There is something more dangerous than a broken process. A process that appears to work. Most engineering organizations today are not chaotic. They are structured. But when AI changes where effort lives, those same structures begin to distort reality.
chapters.section: Part 2 — What Actually Changed (Not the Hype)
